Are you tired? Fatigue may be caused by certain behaviors or habits but they can be easy to change. There are some common things that cause fatigue some easy and helpful tips to help you combat fatigue.
Do you exercise? Fitting in 30 minutes of exercise at least 4 times a week will improve you energy level and help you sleep better at night.
Do you sleep regularly? The more your sleeping patterns change from day to day, the more tired you'll become. Try to stay consistent about when you go to bed and wake – even on the weekends.
Are you drinking enough water? Dehydration causes your body to conserve energy by decreasing blood circulation. Be sure to drink eight glasses of water each day.
Do you slouch? Poor posture causes your body to work harder than it does when your body is aligned correctly. Make sure you are sitting or standing straight and stretch out your tired muscles periodically.
Do you have a sweet tooth? Simple sugars, found in junk food, may give you a quick boost of energy-but once it wears off, it will leave you more tired. Avoid too many sweets during the day.
Follow these simple tips to keep your energy levels high!

Do you have a hard time remembering names? The ability to remember the names of people you meet will always serve you well in social situations. Here are some tips to help you remember people’s names.
Firstly, pay attention when you are introduced to someone. Once you get their name, use it several times in the conversation.“ Hi, John, nice to meet you. So, what do you do for a living John? John, it was great to meet you!” Saying it immediately and using it right away will help you remember it.
After you’ve spoken to them, write down the new name while picturing the person's face; do this as soon as possible after meeting someone. If this isn’t possible, just imagine writing the name, visualize the name, and say it to yourself as it will help you remember it.
Use word associations. Connect a name to a common word or a familiar image that you will remember. For example, the name Ryan sounds like lion and you can remember the name if you associate it with the word lion or a picture of a lion. Or you can remember someone named James by associating him with James bond in your mind.
Try these tips and they are sure to help you remember people’s names!

Hangovers are horrible. Headaches and nausea can feel awful. Unfortunately, there is no absolute cure or prevention for hangovers, but there are things you can do to lessen their effects.
One approach is to stay hydrated. Alcohol causes dehydration, which worsens the symptoms of a hangover. Drinking a lot of water will keep you hydrated. You can try drinking a lot of water at the end of the night, or you can keep your self hydrated throughout the night.
Another approach is to slow down the effects of alcohol by drinking with a meal and not drinking on an empty stomach. Food keeps alcohol in your stomach longer and it is processed more slowly.
Some say that drinking Only Light-Colored Alcohol – such as white wine, vodka, and gin prevents serious hangovers because lighter drinks have fewer headache-inducing ingredients than darker drinks - like red wine, beer and dark liquors. This only works if you drink in moderation, though.
These are just a few options that different people use in order to prevent hangovers. Again, there really isn’t much you can do to prevent or cure hangovers, but different people have different methods that they swear by. The most important thing is to drink in more moderation for your health and safety.

Do you ever feel like your brain is slowing down or that you can’t seem to get your mind to work as quickly as you want? Experts say that intelligence doesn’t change over time, but you do need to keep your brain in shape and improve your cognitive performance.
Remember that most older people think more clearly in the morning; most younger people, in the afternoon. Figure out your own best time and use it for your most challenging brain work.
Expose yourself to diverse experiences and new knowledge. Making yourself adapt to different environments and situations keep your brain in shape. Also, learning and repeatedly practicing new skills keeps things organized and set in your mind.
Leonardo da Vinci is said to have learned to juggle and draw with his opposite hand. Try such brain-challenging activities to keep your mind in shape.
Pay attention. Oftentimes, the problem isn't memory; it's concentration. We must consciously remind ourselves to put information into our memory banks.
Exercise the body to improve the mind. Increasing oxygen and nutrients supplied to the brain promotes brain cell growth.
It isn’t difficult to keep your brain in top condition by following these simple tips. Remind yourself to keep learning and stretching your brain.

Do you have trouble falling asleep? People often have a hard time falling asleep because they have so many things on their minds and so many thoughts still runny through their brain. What can you do to let go of the day's worries so you can sleep at night? Here are some tips you can try.
Turn off the TV. Let your mind settle into a peaceful state by not filling it with more stimuli from TV programs.
Record your thoughts in a journal before you get to bed. This can be a good way to unload anything that's bothering or worrying you.
Listen to mellow music to help your mind and body unwind, and also to stabilize your brain patterns. A slower beat stimulates the right hemisphere of the brain ― the area that's in charge of order, balance, and peace.
Some other things that you can do to help fall asleep are: drink something warm – such as warm milk or herbal tea. The warmth temporarily increases your body temperature, and often brings on sleepiness. Also, briefly massaging your head and feet can prepare you for a restful sleep.
Try these simple tips to help yourself unwind before bed so that you can fall asleep faster.

What is the best way to fuel your body for a workout? Here are some simple guidelines to follow.
If you’ve had a balanced meal within the last three hours, you shouldn’t need to eat anything before hitting the gym. If it’s been longer than three hours, a light snack high in complex carbohydrates and low in sugar will continuous fuel throughout a workout.
For moderate workouts that last approximately an hour or less, be sure to stay hydrated by drinking water every 15 to 20 minutes. If your workout is more intense, have a sports drink such as Gatorade to replace some of the electrolytes you’ve lost.
For after your workout, if your workout was pretty serious, like an intense cardiovascular routine, try to have a full meal within an hour that combines protein, a blend of simple and complex carbs, and healthy fat. These healing nutrients will help repair and feed tired muscles. And rehydrate yourself with fluid from food such as fruit and vegetables or non-caffeinated beverages. Eat the same things in lighter from after less intense workouts.
Properly fuelling your body before, during and after a workout will help you stay energized and safe as you improve your health.

Do you ever feel like things are too hectic in your life? Here are some simple changes you can make to simplify your life.
Keep track of important dates and event electronically. Trying to remember everything yourself can weigh you down. The latest way to keep track of birthdays, appointments, life events, or daily reminders is to sign up for an Internet reminder service. If you sign up for these Internet reminder services, you'll receive alerts on your computer or PDA.
Delegate your tasks. Trying to get everything done yourself can leave you feeling exhausted and resentful at the end of the day. Often people don’t like to delegate tasks because they want to get things done their way or because they feel like it may be a sign of weakness, but actually, delegating is a great way to get organized. It’s about responsibility, vision and common sense.
Don’t be a perfectionist. Excellence and trying your best is commendable, but aiming for perfection in everything you do is counterintuitive to simplifying your life. Let go of the unnecessary expectations in your life and enjoy things even if they aren’t perfect.
Small attitude changes in your life can make a big difference in simplifying your life.

Consider these basic options as you choose the best watch for you.

Secondhand stress, like secondhand smoke, can be very harmful to you. Someone else’s stress can make your body release stress hormones, affect your perspective, lead to relationship tension, cause physical and emotional fatigue etc. How can you best cope with contagious stress? Experts say that there are ways to remain compassionate, understanding, and empathetic without letting other people’s stress affect you negatively.
The best coping strategy is to tell the other person directly how their stress is affecting you. Remember that there are ways to express your concern -- and voice your stress -- empathetically. Ask how you can help, but set realistic limits.
Another strategy that experts recommend is to work on regulating your feelings and responses. It’s not easy to do so when you are feeling stressed yourself, but try to back away from the situation and figure out the most logical course of action with an objective perspective.
Finally, you should regularly give yourself time to get away from your stressors, unwind, reduce stress and recharge. Even if it’s something simple, do something that makes you happy and increases your positive feelings.
Don’t let other people’s stress weigh you down. Be proactive and handling even the contagious stress around you.

Driving in a crowded city is not an easy thing to do. On traffic filled roads, it’s easy to fall into the pitfalls of road rage – which refers to violent behavior on the road including speeding, excessive honking, shouting verbal abuse, etc. Here are some simple but effective tips to help curb anger and frustration on the road:
Change your Outlook: When another driver angers you on the road, try to put things into perspective. It’s not the end of the world nor cause for a fit that will not do any good. Take some deep breaths, get over it, and move on.
Relax in your car. Keep yourself rage-free by creating a relaxing and comfortable environment in your car. A good place to start is by listening to some relaxing music that you enjoy.
Give Yourself Time: If you’re running late and trying to beat the traffic it’s inevitable that you’ll become stressed out, which can then turn into frustration and rage towards other drivers. So always allow plenty of time for your trip.
Slow Down: Respect the speed limits. Saving a few minutes is not worth a potential ticket, or worse, a potential accident.
Don’t let road rage get the best of you on the road!

When was the last time you wrote or received a letter? A letter can have special powers. It can be more personal and touching than a conversation or a phone call. Here are some tips on writing letters:
It's a good idea to mentally go over the main things you want to say before starting. You can begin with some general topics like some good news, what you've been doing lately, or maybe refer to the last time you met the person you are writing to. Keep the tone conversational, and let it flow naturally.
When writing thank-you letters, be sure to thank the person for the specific gift and mention the gift by name. It’s also nice to acknowledge the effort and energy the giver put into getting the gift and let them know how you have used or will use the gift.
If you have offended someone and are sorry for it, the best thing to do is apologize in person and follow it up with a letter. When writing an apology letter, it must say clearly and humbly that you are sorry. If there is some way you can make amends, promise to do so.
Keep these things in mind when writing letters.

What do you take when you have a headache or minor pain? Many people take aspirin to relieve headache pain, reduce fever and inflammation. It is a common, cheap and simple non-prescription drug. You do however need to use aspirin sensibly and safely. Here are some tips to remember:
Do not take aspirin on an empty stomach. It can cause upset stomach or heartburn if you don’t take it with food. To help avoid these problems, it is recommended that aspirin be taken at or after meals
If you feel that you need to take aspirin for more than a few days, consult a doctor. You should avoid exceeding a dose of 1g –which is 3 tablets - 4 times a day except on doctor's advice. Too much aspirin can cause unwanted side-effects.
As with all medicines, do not take alcohol with aspirin. Aspirin can increase alcohol absorption and also affect liver function.
If you are taking any other treatment suggested by a doctor, ask him or her if it is safe to take aspirin as well. Mixing medication can be dangerous.
Remember that aspirin is a convenient, but powerful medicine, so it’s best treat it with respect.

Do you send a lot of text messages on your phone? With the advance this convenient communication tool, the number of people who send text messages is growing. An interesting fact is that among these people who are sending text messages regularly, there is also a growing number of people who are straining the tendons in their thumbs and forearms because of overuse of small devices and their small buttons.
The problem typically occurs when people use small gadgets such as cell phones or other handheld devices by moving their palms together and using their thumbs in a strained position. This position can strain the tendons that go from the thumb to the wrist. Experts suggest keeping your palms and wrists comfortably apart to cause the least strain on your hands and forearms.
Luckily, treatment usually doesn't involve anything more serious than rest, possibly the use of anti-inflammatory medication and in really bad cases, a splint.
Not everyone may experience pain or strain in their thumbs from the use of handheld gadgets, but the growing number of problems – especially in children and teenagers – is cause for people to be more aware about the possible effects of overusing these devices.

Do you ever experience a serious a case of the blues? Everyone goes through times of feeling low – but if those times are prolonged – they can bring unwanted side effects into your life. Here are self-help methods that may help you feel balanced and content once more
Share your experiences: Talking to a positive and supportive friend or relative will help. It will also make you feel less isolated.
Make time to relax: Depression is frequently associated with tension, stress and anxiety. Relaxation is one of the best treatments for this. Find out what works for you and give yourself time to unwind.
Get out and exercise: Feeling the blues is often accompanied by a loss of energy and constant feelings of tiredness. Taking some form of gentle exercise will make you feel more positive, and release endorphins.
Pursue interests: Try to continue with any hobbies or interests you have. It may be difficult while you are feeling down, especially if you have difficulty concentrating, but it will help you to feel better.
Don’t let the blues get you down. Times of feeling low are normal, but make sure you know how to overcome them and pick yourself up.

Do you have trouble sleeping at night? Insomnia is the chronic inability to fall asleep or remain asleep for an adequate length of time. If you suffer from insomnia, it can cause serious disturbances in your lifestyle. Experts say that a carefully planned out eating plan can put an end to long, sleepless nights.
The carbohydrates in food help our bodies produce serotonin - a sleep-inducing hormone. Following a meal plan that incorporates plenty of healthy carbohydrate-rich foods like brown rice, fruit, pasta, potatoes, and oatmeal can provides sufficient amounts of serotonin in your system. Another food that will help you is milk – as contains tryptophan, an amino acid that promotes sleep.
Digesting a big dinner can prevent you from resting comfortably. But also remember that a light snack in the evening can help you sleep – try warm milk, chamomile tea, or some complex carbohydrates.
Try to avoid caffeine throughout the day, and especially during the evening. And don’t use alcohol as a sleep aid - it actually causes restless sleep and should be avoided.
Try these simple tips and you will be on your way to restful night’s sleep.

Can you tell the difference between a cold and the flu? You may think the flu is just a worse version of a cold but it's important to recognize the symptoms of both.
A cold is a minor viral or bacterial infection of the nose and throat and can occur in any season. Seeing a doctor when you have a cold is unnecessary for most healthy people. The flu, short for influenza, is a viral disease of the respiratory tract and is highly contagious.
The flu's symptoms come on suddenly and include a high fever, headache, aches and pains, tiredness, weakness and chest discomfort or coughing. Sometimes it involves a stuffy nose, sneezing and sore throat. A cold, on the other hand, rarely causes a fever, headache, exhaustion or aches and pains. Its most obvious symptoms are a stuffy nose, sneezing, sore throat and cough.
The flu has the potential to develop into other complications and should be treated quickly. The good news is that the flu is preventable if you get vaccinated. A flu vaccine is recommended every year.
For your health, it’s important to recognize the difference between a cold and the flu.

Have you ever considered weight training? Weight training builds and maintains muscle mass, protects the health of your cardiovascular system, prevents weight gain, keeps your blood pressure low, boosts your mood, keeps depression at bay, boosts energy, and improves your balance. If you're not doing it now, you should. Here are some things to keep in mind:
Many people are wary of weight training because they think it will make them look bigger. You will get a little bit bigger because you're building muscle before you've burned off fat, but once you burn off the fat you'll look tighter and smaller.
Experts say that doing 20 minute weight training sessions two or three times a week is enough to gain its health benefits. It is also recommended that you do one set of eight to 12 repetitions for each exercise, but you'll build endurance and burn more calories if you do more sets. Try to aim for one to three sets.
Remember also not to lift weights too slowly or too quickly. You will either be training your muscles to be slow or just be lifting using momentum. It’s best to lift at an even, natural rate.
Remember these tips and get started on weight training!

Do you pay attention to your oral health? We all know that good oral can help prevent bad breath, tooth decay and gum disease – but did you know that a healthy mouth may help you ward off medical disorders? Research shows that an unhealthy mouth may increase your risk of serious health problems such as heart attack, stroke, poorly controlled diabetes etc. It’s important to understand the importance of oral health — and its connection to your overall health.
More than 500 species of bacteria thrive in your mouth at any given moment. These bacteria constantly form dental plaque — a sticky, colorless film that can cling to your teeth and cause health problems. If you don't brush and floss regularly plaque can build up along your gumline, creating an environment for gum infection. These oral bacteria can be dangerous to you if your immune system is not strong. They can enter your blood stream and cause infections in other parts of your body. Long term gum infection can lead to the loss of your teeth as well as serious health disorders.
Make it a priority to practice good oral hygiene every day. You're making an investment in your overall health for now and for your future.

However, a recent study has found that merely cutting back on the number of cigarettes did not lower a smoker's risk of early death. A research team in Oslo has reported that limiting the daily amount of cigarettes may be helpful when a smoker is trying to quit, but kicking the habit and quitting completely is the only real way of reducing the risk of smoking-related health consequences and early death.
The team studied more than 51,000 men and women ranging in age from 20 to 34. At the start of the study, they were first assessed for risk factors. The participants were screened again two more times over a period of 20 years. This extensive study showed that death risks were not lowered for people who merely smoked less – only for those who actually quit.
People may be misled if they're told that cutting back on their smoking may help them keep away disease and early death.

Is brown sugar more nutritious than white? Many people seem to think so because usually the brown version of things like bread, pasta and rice are better for you. That’s because those foods are unrefined, less processed and contain more vitamins, minerals and fiber than the white version. Although brown bread and brown rice are more nutritious than white bread and white rice, brown sugar is not more nutritious than white sugar.
When it comes to sugar, there is no nutritional difference between white and brown because brown sugar is simply white sugar coated in molasses – which is a brown syrup that is produced when making sugar.
The fact is that sugar – brown or white - does not provide any vitamins or minerals. They only provide calories and sweet flavoring. This can be bad news for people who are watching their weight or health. Many people will opt for brown sugar instead of white under the mistaken assumption that it is providing more than just calories.
Remember, however, that sugar is sugar. It’s best to only consume sugar in moderation.

Do you like to be in control? Do you have a need to be in control at all times? In other words, are you a control freak? A control freak is someone who wants to be in control of every situation they find themselves in. It can be very difficult to deal with a control freak so here are some tips on avoiding becoming one.
Avoid Always Needing the Last Word. Be clear and brief on your point when you speak. Only say what will bring success to the goal at hand. Once you have stated you point, avoid saying anything unnecessary.
Evaluate your Intentions. Remember that only reason to make a strong point is when the situation is disrupting what needs to be done. Every other point should be made in a positive manner.
Use positive and affirming Body Language. Sit eye to eye and don’t convey negative emotions. Remember, you don’t need to be overbearing to make a point.
Give in graciously when necessary. Be open to the fact that you could be wrong. When you are, accept it and say you were wrong.
Remember that there is a big difference between being a strong person and being a control freak.
